content:
To see contributor disclosures related to this article, click on this reference: [1]

Physicians can earn CME/MOC credit by using this article to address a clinical question and completing a brief evaluation about how they applied the information in their practice.

AMBOSS designates this internet point-of-care activity for a maximum of 0.5 AMA PRA Category 1 Credit(s)™. Physicians should only claim credit commensurate with the extent of their participation in the activity.

For answers to questions about AMBOSS CME, including how to redeem CME/MOC credit, see "Tips and links" at the bottom of this article.

Diagnostic approach

  • ABCDE survey
  • Targeted clinical evaluation
  • Pregnancy test
  • CBC
  • Type and screen
  • Quantitative β-hCG
  • Coagulation studies
  • Transvaginal ultrasound

Red flag features

  • Hemodynamic instability (e.g., hemorrhagic shock)
  • Abdominal and/or pelvic pain
  • Peritoneal signs
  • Vaginal bleeding in pregnancy
  • Postmenopausal bleeding

Life-threatening causes

  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Incomplete abortion
  • Placental abruption
  • Placenta previa
  • Vasa previa
  • Uterine rupture
  • Genitourinary trauma

Management checklist

  • Manage hemorrhagic shock.
  • Reverse anticoagulants if indicated.
  • Administer anti-D immunoglobulin to non-sensitized RhD-negative pregnant patients.
  • Treat the underlying cause.
  • Consult OB/GYN as needed.

Vaginal bleeding that cannot be attributed to expected menstrual bleeding is a common clinical presentation. The most likely underlying cause depends on the patient’s pregnancy status, reproductive stage, and other factors (e.g., use of hormone replacement therapy, risk factors for gynecologic malignancies). Vaginal bleeding in nonpregnant adults encompasses abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) in premenopausal individuals, postmenopausal bleeding, and postcoital bleeding. Common etiologies in these individuals include causes of AUB (i.e., PALM-COEIN), cervicitis, and vulvovaginal atrophy. Vaginal bleeding in pregnant individuals has different causes at < 20 weeks' gestation (e.g., ectopic pregnancy, spontaneous abortion) and > 20 weeks' gestation (e.g., placenta previa, placental abruption); the latter are detailed in “Antepartum hemorrhage.” Premenarchal vaginal bleeding can be caused by precocious puberty, retained vaginal foreign bodies, trauma, and rarely, tumors. Vaginal bleeding in adolescents is usually due to causes of AUB. In all patients, diagnosis involves a focused history and examination and targeted testing based on clinical suspicion. A urine pregnancy test should be obtained in patients who can become pregnant. When imaging is required, transvaginal ultrasound (TVUS) is the preferred modality in premenopausal individuals and early pregnancy; transabdominal ultrasound is an option in later pregnancy and in children and adolescents. Malignancy (e.g., endometrial cancer) must be ruled out in all postmenopausal individuals; endometrial sampling must be performed if indications for endometrial sampling exist. Trauma (including sexual trauma), coagulopathy, and endocrine disorders are common nonobstetric, nongynecologic causes of bleeding that should be evaluated if clinically suspected. Treatment is based on the underlying cause.

Definitions

  • Abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB): any of the following (see “FIGO-AUB classification system 1” for details) [2]
    • Abnormal bleeding (classified according to frequency, duration, regularity, and volume)
    • Intermenstrual bleeding
    • Unscheduled bleeding
  • Postmenopausal bleeding: bleeding that occurs ≥ 12 months after the onset of permanent amenorrhea due to age-related loss of ovarian follicular function [3][4]
  • Postcoital bleeding: spotting or bleeding that occurs during or after intercourse and is unrelated to menstruation [5]

Etiology [6][7][8][9]

Many of these conditions manifest with either painful or painless bleeding depending on several factors (e.g., severity, stage, location). See also “Causes of abnormal uterine bleeding.”

Painless bleeding

  • Endometrial causes
    • Endometrial polyps
    • Endometrial hyperplasia
    • Endometrial cancer (early stages)
    • Endometrial atrophy [9]
  • Cervical causes
    • Cervical ectropion
    • Cervical polyps
    • Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) or cervical cancer (early stages)
  • Other causes
    • Ovulatory dysfunction (e.g., due to endocrine disorders such as hypothyroidism, hyperprolactinemia, or polycystic ovary syndrome)
    • Coagulopathies (e.g., von Willebrand disease)
    • Iatrogenic, e.g.,
      • IUD displacement
      • Adverse effects of medications such as hormone replacement therapy, oral contraceptives, or tamoxifen [3]

Painful bleeding

  • Endometrial causes
    • Adenomyosis
    • Uterine leiomyoma
    • Endometrial dysfunction (e.g., pelvic inflammatory disease, chronic endometritis)
    • Endometriosis
    • Endometrial cancer (advanced stages)
  • Cervical causes
    • Cervicitis
    • Cervical cancer (advanced stages) [3]
  • Vulvovaginal causes
    • Vaginal injuries, including sexual abuse
    • Vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia (VaIN) or vaginal cancer
    • Vulvovaginal atrophy, e.g., due to genitourinary syndrome of menopause (GSM) [10]
    • Vulvovaginitis
    • Retained foreign body
  • Other causes
    • Ruptured ovarian cyst
    • Postoperative complications

Clinical evaluation

Focused history [6][11]

  • Onset, duration, frequency, and amount of bleeding
  • Associated symptoms, e.g.:
    • Pelvic pain
    • Vaginal discharge
    • Dyspareunia in women
    • Symptoms of bleeding disorders
    • Symptoms of hypothyroidism
  • Sexual history
  • Gynecologic and obstetric history
  • Current and past medication review
  • Relevant risk factors, e.g.:
    • Risk factors for ectopic pregnancy
    • Risk factors for cervical cancer
    • Risk factors for endometrial cancer
    • Risk factors for STIs
  • Family history (e.g., of gynecological malignancies, bleeding disorders)

Focused examination [6][11]

  • Vital signs: for features of hemodynamic instability
  • Abdominal examination
  • Pelvic examination
    • External genital examination: Inspect the external anogenital region and urethral orifice for any sources of bleeding.
    • Bimanual examination: Assess for uterine enlargement, adnexal masses, and cervical motion tenderness.
    • Speculum examination: Assess for vaginal and cervical sources of bleeding.
  • Assessment for clinical features of genitourinary trauma
  • Evaluation for nonobstetric and nongynecologic causes of bleeding as indicated, e.g.:
    • Clinical features of bleeding disorders
    • Examination of the thyroid gland
    • Clinical features of hyperandrogenism

Use a trauma-informed approach during the clinical evaluation, especially if sexual assault is suspected.

Diagnosis

  • Obtain a urine pregnancy test in all individuals who can become pregnant if pregnancy status is unknown. [6]
  • Perform diagnostics for menopause if the patient's menopausal status is unclear.
  • Tailor diagnostic approach and management based on menopausal status and nature of bleeding; see the respective sections.

Approach [6]

See “Diagnosis of AUB” and “Treatment of AUB” for comprehensive management.

  • Hemodynamically unstable patients
    • Manage hemorrhagic shock with immediate hemodynamic support including emergency blood transfusion.
    • Reverse anticoagulants if indicated.
    • Consult OB/GYN and/or interventional radiology urgently.
    • Consider acute pharmacological treatment of AUB (e.g., high-dose estrogen, tranexamic acid).
    • Perform emergency preoperative evaluation if surgery or uterine artery embolization is indicated (see “Surgery for AUB”).
  • Hemodynamically stable patients: Identify and treat the underlying cause.

Rule out pregnancy in any premenopausal patient who presents with vaginal bleeding.

Common causes

See also “PALM-COEIN system.”

Common causes of AUB [6][11]
Characteristic clinical features Diagnostic findings Management
Polycystic ovary syndrome
  • Clinical features of PCOS, e.g.:
    • Hirsutism
    • Obesity
    • Acne vulgaris
    • Infertility
  • ↑ LH:FSH ratio, AMH, and androgens
  • TVUS: enlarged or polycystic ovaries
  • Lifestyle changes
  • Pharmacological treatment (e.g., COCs, metformin)
  • See “Treatment of PCOS.”
Uterine leiomyoma [11][12]
  • Back/pelvic pain
  • Infertility
  • Urinary tract or bowel symptoms
  • Dyspareunia
  • Dysmenorrhea
  • Firm, irregular, enlarged uterus [13]
  • Ultrasound (best initial test): well-circumscribed hypoechoic solid mass [14]
  • Minimal symptoms: expectant management
  • Pharmacological treatment
    • GnRH agonists
    • CHCs, progestin-only contraception
  • Procedural interventions (e.g., uterine artery embolization, myomectomy, hysterectomy)
Adenomyosis [15][16]
  • Chronic pelvic pain
  • Dyspareunia
  • Uniformly enlarged, mildly tender uterus
  • Dysmenorrhea
  • Imaging (TVUS, MRI): asymmetric myometrial thickening
  • Biopsy (selected patients): histopathological confirmation [17]
  • Pain management (first line: NSAIDs)
  • Hormonal therapy (e.g., CHCs, progestin-only contraception)
  • Surgery
    • Conservative: hysteroscopic endometrial excision, ablation
    • Definitive: hysterectomy
Endometrial polyps [18][19][20]
  • May be asymptomatic
  • Infertility
  • Recurrent pregnancy loss
  • Dysmenorrhea
  • TVUS: focal echogenic endometrial mass with preserved endometrial-myometrial interface [20][21]
  • Hysteroscopy or sonohysterography: visualization of polyps
  • Negative endometrial biopsy can rule out other causes.
  • Asymptomatic premenopausal patients: observation and follow-up
  • Symptomatic or risk factors for endometrial cancer: hysteroscopic polypectomy
  • See “Treatment” in “Endometrial polyps” for details.
Endometrial hyperplasia or cancer
  • Risk factors for endometrial cancer
  • Patients with cancer may present with
    • Pelvic pain
    • Bowel and bladder symptoms
  • TVUS: endometrial thickening > 4 mm
  • Endometrial sampling: histopathological confirmation
    • Endometrial hyperplasia: proliferation of glandular tissue with or without atypia
    • Endometrial cancer: disorganized glandular tissue with cellular atypia
  • See “Endometrial hyperplasia” and “Treatment of endometrial cancer” for details.
Bleeding disorders
  • Clinical features of bleeding disorders, e.g.:
    • Epistaxis
    • Bleeding gums
    • Bruising
    • Procedural bleeding
  • Family history of bleeding disorders
  • Findings vary by specific disorder and may include:
    • Thrombocytopenia
    • ↑ PT/INR and PTT
  • See “Laboratory findings in bleeding disorders” for details.
  • Treatment depends on underlying cause.
  • See “Treatment of bleeding disorders” for details.
Medications
  • Use of medications that may cause bleeding, e.g.:
    • Hormonal contraception
    • Antithrombotic agents
    • NSAIDs
  • Clinical diagnosis
  • Discontinuation of contributing medications, if possible

Approach [3][8][22]

Individuals not on HRT

  • Assess for risk factors for endometrial cancer.
    • No risk factors and first episode of bleeding: Perform TVUS or endometrial sampling.
    • Risk factors or other indications for endometrial sampling present: Perform endometrial sampling.
  • Determine need for further testing.
    • Abnormal endometrial sampling: Refer to a specialist for additional evaluation.
    • Endometrial thickness ≤ 4mm on TVUS and/or normal endometrial sampling: No further testing.
    • Endometrial thickness > 4 mm or inadequate visualization on TVUS: Perform endometrial sampling if not already performed.
    • Endometrial sampling insufficient for diagnosis: Consider TVUS if not already performed. [8]
    • Persistent or recurrent symptoms:
      • Obtain hysteroscopy-guided endometrial sampling if not already performed.
      • Otherwise, refer to specialist for additional evaluation.
  • Evaluate for other common causes of PMB as indicated.
  • Treat underlying cause.

Individuals on HRT [4]

  • Refer to a specialist.
  • Diagnostic studies (e.g., TVUS, endometrial sampling) may be indicated depending on:
    • Presence of risk factors for endometrial cancer
    • Extent of bleeding
    • Time since HRT initiation or dosage change [3][4]
  • Adjust HRT regimen if indicated.

A comprehensive evaluation of all individuals with PMB is essential to rule out endometrial cancer and endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia. [8]

Common causes

Common causes of postmenopausal bleeding [22]
Characteristic clinical features Diagnostic findings Management
Genitourinary syndrome of menopause [10][23][24]
  • Vaginal dryness and burning
  • Dyspareunia
  • Urinary symptoms
  • Speculum examination: vaginal friability, pallor, petechiae, or ulcerations
  • Clinical diagnosis
  • ↑ FSH
  • Vaginal moisturizers and lubricants
  • Hormone therapy (vaginal and/or systemic HRT) or nonhormonal therapy (SERM)
  • See “Genitourinary syndrome of menopause” for details.
Endometrial polyps [18][19]
  • Risk factors for endometrial polyps may be present
  • TVUS: focal echogenic endometrial mass with preserved endometrial-myometrial interface [20][21]
  • Hysteroscopy or sonohysterography: visualization of polyps
  • Selected asymptomatic premenopausal patients: expectant management
  • Most other patients: hysteroscopic polypectomy
  • See “Endometrial polyps” for details.
Endometrial hyperplasia [25][26]
  • Risk factors for endometrial cancer may be present
  • Pelvic examination may be normal.
  • TVUS: endometrial thickening > 4 mm [8]
  • Endometrial sampling with histology: proliferation of glandular tissue with or without atypia
  • Mitigate excess estrogen.
  • Endometrial hyperplasia without atypia: progestin (preferred) or monitoring
  • Endometrial hyperplasia with atypia: hysterectomy or progestin with monitoring
  • See “Endometrial hyperplasia” for details.
Endometrial cancer [27]
  • Pelvic pain
  • Bowel and bladder symptoms in advanced stages
  • TVUS: endometrial thickening > 4 mm
  • Endometrial sampling with histology: disorganized glandular tissue with cellular atypia
  • Total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy
  • Locally advanced disease: adjuvant chemotherapy and/or radiotherapy
  • See “Treatment of endometrial cancer” for details.
Cervical cancer [28][29]
  • Postcoital spotting
  • May have abnormal vaginal discharge
  • Pelvic pain
  • Dyspareunia
  • Colposcopy: exophytic mass, ulceration with or without acetowhitening [30]
  • Confirmatory biopsy: tumor invasion beyond basement membrane of cervical epithelium
  • Early disease: surgery (preferred) or radiotherapy
  • Locally advanced disease: chemoradiotherapy
  • See “Treatment of cervical cancer” for details.

Approach [5][31]

There is currently no standard diagnostic algorithm for postcoital bleeding. Depending on extent and nature of bleeding, perform diagnostics for AUB and evaluation of PMB as indicated.

  • Obtain a pregnancy test in all individuals who can become pregnant.
  • Evaluate for cervical pathology, including:
    • Diagnostics for cervicitis
    • Cervical cancer screening (if not up-to-date)
    • Colposcopy in selected patients, e.g.:
      • As part of risk-based management for abnormal cervical cancer screening results
      • With features suggestive of cervical cancer on pelvic examination
  • For persistent bleeding, refer to gynecology for consideration of additional workup.

Rule out endometrial cancer in postmenopausal patients with postcoital bleeding. [5]

Common causes

Common causes of postcoital bleeding [5][31]
Characteristic clinical features Diagnostic findings Management
Cervical ectropion [5][32]
  • Mucopurulent vaginal discharge
  • Speculum examination: erythema around external cervical os
  • Clinical diagnosis
  • Direct visualization with colposcopy if diagnostic uncertainty
  • Provide reassurance.
  • Consider progestin-only contraception.
  • Persistent symptoms: Consider ablation
Cervicitis [33]
  • Dyspareunia
  • Vaginal discharge
  • Cervical inflammation on speculum examination
  • Clinical diagnosis
  • Pathogen identification (e.g., NAAT for chlamydia and gonorrhea)
  • Treatment of underlying infection
  • STI management of sexual partners
  • See “Treatment of cervicitis.”
PID [33]
  • Lower abdominal or pelvic pain
  • Fever, nausea, vomiting
  • Dyspareunia
  • Vaginal discharge
  • Cervical motion tenderness
  • Clinical diagnosis based on diagnostic criteria for PID
  • Pathogen identification (e.g., NAAT for chlamydia and gonorrhea)
  • Empiric antibiotic therapy for PID
  • Hospitalization for severe cases
  • See “Treatment of PID” for details.
Cervical polyps [32][34]
  • Speculum examination: small, red-purple, pedunculated, fleshy, friable lesion(s) on the ectocervix or protruding from the cervical os
  • Direct visualization on speculum examination
  • Biopsy (at time of removal): benign hyperplastic endocervical epithelium [35]
  • Small and asymptomatic: monitoring
  • Symptomatic: polypectomy
Cervical cancer [28][29]
  • AUB
  • May have abnormal vaginal discharge
  • Pelvic pain
  • Dyspareunia
  • Colposcopy: exophytic mass, ulceration with or without acetowhitening [30]
  • Biopsy: invasion of cervical stroma
  • Early disease: surgery (preferred) or radiotherapy
  • Locally advanced disease: chemoradiotherapy
  • See “Treatment of cervical cancer” for details.
Endometrial polyps [18][36]
  • AUB
  • Infertility
  • TVUS: focal echogenic endometrial mass with preserved endometrial-myometrial interface [20][21]
  • Hysteroscopy or sonohysterography: visualization of polyps
  • Selected asymptomatic premenopausal patients: expectant management
  • Most other patients: hysteroscopic polypectomy
  • See “Endometrial polyps” for details.
Vulvovaginal atrophy [23]
  • Vaginal dryness, pallor, thinning, itching, and burning
  • Dysuria
  • Dyspareunia
  • Clinical diagnosis
  • Findings related to the underlying cause
  • Vaginal moisturizers and lubricants
  • Treat underlying cause, e.g.:
    • Discontinue triggering medications.
    • Treat GSM.
    • Treat radiation-induced sexual dysfunction.
Vaginal injuries
  • Recent sexual activity
  • Dyspareunia
  • Visible laceration, bruising, or abrasions on vaginal or cervical examination
  • Clinical diagnosis
  • Local wound care
  • See “Vulvar and vaginal injuries” and “Management of recent sexual violence.”

The underlying cause of postcoital bleeding remains unclear in the majority of patients, but bleeding often resolves spontaneously. [5]

Etiology [37][38][39][40]

All patients

  • Postcoital bleeding
  • Trauma in pregnancy
  • Bleeding disorders

Early pregnancy bleeding (patients < 20 weeks' gestation)

  • Painless
    • Implantation bleeding
    • Threatened abortion
  • Painful
    • Ectopic pregnancy or heterotopic pregnancy
    • Spontaneous abortion
    • Subchorionic hematoma
    • Gestational trophoblastic disease

Antepartum hemorrhage (patients > 20 weeks' gestation)

  • Painless
    • Placenta previa
    • Vasa previa
  • Painful
    • Placental abruption (e.g., due to trauma in pregnancy)
    • Uterine rupture
  • See “Differential diagnosis of antepartum bleeding” for a more comprehensive list.

Postpartum hemorrhage (delivery to 12 weeks postpartum)

  • Primary postpartum hemorrhage (≤ 24 hours postpartum)
    • Uterine atony
    • Abnormal placental separation
    • Birth trauma
  • Secondary postpartum hemorrhage (24 hours to 12 weeks postpartum)
    • Retained products of conception
    • Coagulation disorders
  • See “Differential diagnosis of postpartum hemorrhage” for a more comprehensive list.

Initial management [38][39][41][42]

  • Assess hemodynamic status.
  • Hemodynamically unstable patients
    • Manage hemorrhagic shock with immediate hemodynamic support including emergency blood transfusion.
    • Urgently consult OB/GYN to evaluate the need for emergency surgery.
  • RhD-negative individuals: Provide management of RhD-negative individuals during pregnancy.
  • Identify and treat the underlying cause (see “Common causes of vaginal bleeding in pregnancy”).
  • See also:
    • “Management of ruptured ectopic pregnancy”
    • “Initial management of antepartum hemorrhage” for patients > 20 weeks' gestation
    • “Postpartum hemorrhage”

Administer anti-D immunoglobulin to all nonsensitized RhD-negative pregnant patients with vaginal bleeding, ideally within 72 hours of symptom onset. [43]

Clinical evaluation [38][39]

Focused history

  • Onset, duration, frequency, and amount of bleeding
  • Prior bleeding episodes during pregnancy
  • Associated symptoms (e.g., pain)
  • Obstetric and gynecologic history
  • Relevant risk factors, e.g.:
    • Risk factors for ectopic pregnancy
    • Risk factors for spontaneous abortion

Focused examination

  • Vital signs: for features of hemodynamic instability
  • Clinical assessment of volume status
  • Abdominal examination, including assessment for peritoneal signs
  • Pelvic examination
    • All patients: external genital examination
    • In patients < 20 weeks' gestation, perform a bimanual and speculum examination to assess for:
      • Nonobstetric causes of bleeding (e.g., infection, cervical polyps)
      • Adnexal masses or tenderness
      • Products of conception
      • Open or closed cervical os
    • In patients > 20 weeks' gestation, do not perform a pelvic examination until after placenta previa and vasa previa have been excluded on TVUS.

In pregnant patients > 20 weeks' gestation with vaginal bleeding, evaluate the placenta with TVUS before performing a pelvic examination. [7]

Diagnostics [38][39][42][44]

  • All patients
    • Obtain CBC and type and screen.
    • Consider additional laboratory studies based on clinical suspicion (e.g., coagulation studies in patients with suspected bleeding disorders). [38]
  • Patients < 20 weeks' gestation: Obtain β-hCG and TVUS. [40][45][46]
    • Sonographic signs of intrauterine pregnancy (IUP): Manage as threatened abortion; see “Spontaneous abortion” for details. [47]
    • TVUS findings of pregnancy failure: See “Spontaneous abortion.” [47]
    • TVUS findings suggestive of ectopic pregnancy: Perform diagnostics for ectopic pregnancy. [48]
    • Pregnancy of unknown location: Arrange close follow-up (e.g., within 48 hours) for re-evaluation. [7][49]
  • Patients > 20 weeks' gestation [40]
    • Obtain TVUS and/or transabdominal ultrasound to assess for placenta previa and vasa previa.
    • Perform electronic fetal heart rate monitoring.
    • See “Antepartum hemorrhage” for additional details.
  • Postpartum hemorrhage: usually a clinical diagnosis; may be supplemented by ultrasound (see “Postpartum hemorrhage” for details) [42]

Suspect ectopic pregnancy in all patients with vaginal bleeding unless IUP is confirmed on ultrasound. Consider heterotopic pregnancy in patients receiving infertility treatment. [45][46]

TVUS is the preferred imaging modality to evaluate bleeding in the first trimester of pregnancy. [45]

Common causes of vaginal bleeding in pregnancy

  • For patients > 20 weeks' gestation, see “Causes of antepartum hemorrhage.”
  • For postpartum patients, see “Overview of common causes of postpartum hemorrhage.”
Common causes of vaginal bleeding in early pregnancy (< 20 weeks' gestation) [7][39][44][47]
Characteristic clinical features Diagnostic findings Management
Subchorionic hematoma [37][50]
  • Bleeding in first trimester
  • Possible abdominal pain
  • TVUS: hypoechoic or anechoic gap between gestational sac and uterine wall [51]
  • Expectant management
  • Pelvic rest
  • Fetal growth monitoring after the first trimester
Ectopic pregnancy [48][52]
  • Unilateral lower abdominal pain, guarding
  • Adnexal tenderness
  • Hemorrhagic shock (if ruptured)
  • Ultrasound findings suggestive of ectopic pregnancy
    • Empty uterine cavity
    • Tubal ring sign
    • Adnexal mass
  • Serial β-hCG levels: downtrending
  • Expectant, pharmacological (i.e., methotrexate), or surgical management
  • See “Acute management checklist for ectopic pregnancy.”
Threatened abortion [47]
  • No expulsion of products of conception
  • Closed cervical os
  • IUP confirmed on ultrasound
  • Fetal cardiac activity present
  • Expectant management
  • Pelvic rest [53]
  • Follow up in a week for repeat ultrasound. [39]
  • See “Spontaneous abortion” for details.
Spontaneous abortion [39][47]
  • Abdominopelvic pain or cramping
  • Complete or incomplete abortion: expulsion of products of conception
  • Inevitable or incomplete abortion: open cervical os
  • TVUS: disappearance of previously detected embryonic cardiac activity (see TVUS findings of pregnancy failure) [45]
  • Serial β-hCG levels: downtrending
  • Complete abortion: no treatment required
  • Inevitable, incomplete, or missed abortion: expectant, pharmacological (i.e., mifepristone and misoprostol), or surgical management
  • See “Spontaneous abortion” for details.
Molar pregnancy [54][55]
  • Pelvic pain
  • Complete mole: excessive uterine size, hyperemesis
  • Partial mole: small or appropriate uterine size
  • ↑↑ quantitative serum β-hCG levels
  • TVUS [45][56]
    • Complete mole: hyperechoic uterine mass with multiple cystic spaces, no fetal tissue
    • Partial mole: enlarged placenta with cystic changes, some fetal tissue
  • Fertility preservation desired: uterine evacuation via suction curettage
  • Fertility not desired, especially in patients > 40 years: Consider hysterectomy.
  • Serial β-hCG monitoring [55]

Always consider ectopic pregnancy in individuals with a pregnancy < 20 weeks' gestation who present with vaginal bleeding. [7]

Implantation bleeding, which occurs around the time of expected menses, should also be considered as a benign cause of vaginal spotting or bloody discharge. [37]

Etiology

Premenarchal children [57]

  • Neonatal uterine bleeding
  • Precocious puberty
  • Coagulopathy
  • Retained foreign body (e.g., toilet paper)
  • Vulvovaginitis in children
  • Vaginal injuries or trauma, including child sexual abuse
  • Tumors (e.g., juvenile granulosa cell tumor, rhabdomyosarcoma)

Adolescents [11][58]

Vaginal bleeding in nonpregnant adolescents is usually due to causes of AUB. The most common causes include:

  • Physiological
  • Bleeding disorder
  • Medications (e.g., hormonal contraceptives)
  • Infection (e.g., PID, cervicitis)
  • Tumors

Anovulation and bleeding disorders are the most common causes of heavy menstrual bleeding in adolescents. [58]

Management

Premenarchal children [57][59]

  • Perform a history and external genital examination to assess for:
    • Vulvovaginitis
    • Vaginal injuries
    • Retained foreign bodies
    • Child sexual abuse
  • Determine Tanner stage.
  • If no cause evident on clinical evaluation, refer to a specialist (e.g., gynecology, endocrinology) for further management.

Adolescents [11][58][60]

  • Perform diagnostics for AUB with the following considerations:
    • A speculum examination is typically not necessary.
    • In patients with heavy menstrual bleeding, obtain coagulation panel (including INR and fibrinogen) and diagnostics for von Willebrand disease.
    • Cervical cancer screening is not indicated.
    • Imaging
      • Not routinely recommended as part of the initial workup
      • Consider transabdominal ultrasound as the initial modality when imaging is indicated.
  • Treatment depends on the underlying cause: See “Treatment of AUB.”

Exclude pregnancy as a cause of vaginal bleeding in all sexually active adolescents. [11]

  • Bleeding from the vulva, e.g., due to:
    • Genital herpes
    • Genital warts
    • Vulvar dermatoses (e.g., lichen planus, lichen sclerosus)
    • Vulvar injuries
    • Vulvar cancer
  • Bleeding from the urinary tract, e.g., due to: [57]
    • Urethral prolapse
    • Urethral diverticulum
    • Urethritis
    • Urethral cancer
  • Bleeding from the anal canal, e.g., due to:
    • Hemorrhoids
    • Anal fissures
    • Anorectal tumors
